facts.text: On November 11, 1971, Ram Dia, Dal Singh and Ram Singh went to fields with ploughs; Dal Singh reaping chari crop, Ram Singh ploughing, Ram Dia on round.

facts.text: At about 11 a.m. on November 11, 1971, six accused reached the field armed: Puran and Ram Lal with Suas, Dhanna with Gandasa, Har Lal, Mukhtiara and Chawla with lathis.

facts.text: Chawla, Puran and Ram Lal gave blows to Ram Dia; Ram Singh rescued, assaulted by Dhanna and Mukhtiara; Dal Singh interceded but all six assaulted him.

arguments.claim: Prolonged mental agony from delay mitigates sentence; supported by precedents and penological trends

anchor.surface_text: Still another factor to be taken into account in prescribing the punishment is that death penalty has been brooding over the heads of these young men for an agonisingly long period... ruled that if there has been a long interval between the date of the offence and the consideration of appeal by the Supreme Court... the sentence of death may not be exacted.

arguments.claim: Totality of mitigating circumstances justifies commuting death to life imprisonment

holdings.text: Though this version of the accused was not sufficient to make a case of private defence yet, coupled with the Kanungos report, EX.PJJ, and the surrounding circumstances, it strongly points to the conclusion that the tragedy was probably precipitated by the deceaseds insistence on cultivation and possession of the disputed land including those fields of which actual possession had been duly delivered by the consolidation authorities to the accused.

anchor.surface_text: Though this version of the accused was not sufficient to make a case of private defence yet, coupled with the Kanungos report, EX.PJJ, and the surrounding circumstances, it strongly points to the conclusion that the tragedy was probably precipitated by the deceaseds insistence

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accused's examination under CrPC s.342 plus Kanungo report Ex.PJJ and circumstances show no private defence but probability of provocation by deceased insisting on possession despite delivery to accused.

holdings.text: From Dr. Guptas evidence it is clear that he had caused only one injury, with a lathi, to Ram Dia and his part in the assault, if not less, was in no way greater than that of Har Lal and Ram Lal who had caused no less than six injuries, including two fatal, to the deceased.

anchor.surface_text: Chawla has been awarded the capital sentence for the murder of Ram Dia. The part ascribed to, the appellant by the witnesses, who admittedly had run away to some distance at the commencement of the assault, was that he had inflicted a fatal blow with a lathi on the deceased.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Medical evidence shows contradictory opinions on fatal injuries; only one lathi injury (No.8) attributed to Chawla, not dominant role compared to punctured wounds by others awarded life.

holdings.text: Further circumstance which deserves consideration is that these raw youths, Chawla and Mukhtiara, appear to have acted under the instigation of their elder, Har Lal.

anchor.surface_text: Further circumstance which deserves consideration is that these raw youths, Chawla and Mukhtiara. appear to have acted under the instigation of their elder, Har Lal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellants aged 24-25 are immature and acted at exhortation/instigation of elder Har Lal who incited the group.

holdings.text: Still another factor to be taken into account in prescribing the punishment is that death penalty has been brooding over the heads of these young men for an agonisingly long period... the sentence of death may not be exacted.

anchor.surface_text: Still another factor to be taken into account in prescribing the punishment is that death penalty has been brooding over the heads of these young men for an agonisingly long period. They were committed for trial two Years in February 1972, and were condemned to death by the trial court in April 1972.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Long delay (over 2 years) causes mental agony; precedents like Pashupati Singh recognize it as mitigating despite procedural causes; aligns with penological trends.

holdings.text: But in their totality, they tilt the judicial scales in favour of life rather then putting it out. The circumstances considered above have long been recognised by courts as valid grounds for mitigating the sentence.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Totality of mitigating factors (provocation probability, minor role of Chawla, youth/instigation, delay agony) outweigh aggravating; discretion under s.302 IPC favors life over death; distinguishes state precedents.

holdings.text: We have referred to the modern penological thought and current legislative trends not with a view to decide this case on the basis of what is yet in embryo, but to have a proper perspective for appreciating of the circumstances which have been urged in this case in mitigation of the sentence.

anchor.surface_text: Parliament has passed the Criminal Procedure Code, 1973, which is coming into force shortly, In it, the position is reverse of what it was before the Amendment of 1955. After this Bill becomes law, it will be obligatory for the court to give reasons if the death sentence is to be inflicted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Obiter observation on evolving sentencing norms, CrPC amendments, and new CrPC requiring reasons for death; court exercises existing discretion without needing reasons for life.
